work.title.text: Howard Lane Blackwell and his uncle (probably Henry Browne Blackwell), resting on a lawn. Howard Lane Blackwell is lying on his side in the grass holding a kitten by its neck; Henry Browne Blackwell is asleep next to him with his hat on his chest.

record.work.associated_name: Blackwell, Howard Lane 1877- subject Blackwell, Howard Lane 1877-
Blackwell, Henry Browne 1825-1909 subject Blackwell, Henry Browne 1825-1909

work.related_work.text: Blackwell Family Papers. Folder: Photographs: Blackwell family arranged in birth order: Howard and Helen (Thomas) Blackwell (many taken by HLB): Howard and family (includes brother George Lawrence Blackwell). HOLLIS collection level record 002052619 . RLG collection level record MHVW91-A14.

group.subwork.repository.name: Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America, Radcliffe Institute

work.title.text: Cat and kitten drinking milk, Stolac, Bosnia and Herzegovina

record.work.creator: Parry, Milman 1902-1935 United States photographer Parry, Milman 1902-1935
Lord, Albert Bates 1912-1991 United States photographer Lord, Albert Bates 1912-1991
record.work.place_name: Stolac, Stolac, Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina
record.work.note: General: Photographed by Milman Parry or Albert Lord.

Historical: Born in Oakland, California, in 1902, Milman Parry was a classical scholar educated at the University of California and the Sorbonne. He taught at Harvard University from 1930 until his death in 1935. Parry pioneered the idea that Homer was an oral poet. He made two trips to Yugoslavia between 1933 and 1935 where he studied and recorded South Slavic heroic songs with the help of his assistant Albert Lord (1912-1991), a professor of Slavic and comparative literature at Harvard. Parry observed similarities between the songs he heard in Bosnia and the formulaic verse of Homer's Iliad. After his sudden death, Lord continued and expanded on Parry's research, returning to the Balkans from 1950 to 1951 and eventually documenting their work in the book The Singer of Tales (Harvard University Press, 1960).

work.copyright.statement: Copyright 2004, the Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature and the President and Fellows of Harvard College. Please contact the curators at mpc@fas.harvard.edu with questions about the use of these materials.

work.related_work.text: Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature

work.related_info.description: Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature On-Line Database

record.work.use_restrictions: Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature:Access to the Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature housed in room C of Harvard University's Widener Library is by appointment only. Qualified scholars who wish to use the collection should contact the curatorial staff well in advance of intended visits. Prior notice of several weeks or more will ensure that researchers are able to read and audition the material which will be most useful to them.

work.repository.name: Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature
